options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

What is your overall assessment of this course?

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar, little less than 20 people, one professor, NO TA

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is a great way to familiarize yourself with contemporary empirical economics research and techniques

I learned a lot about both presentation and studying empirical microeconomics research designs. Further, I learned how to replicate data in other studies that I see, by downloading and creating a set of code for myself to test the results. I also honed skills in listening to presentations and being able to best respond to tough questions as well.
Basic understanding on how research is conducted and analyzed for Economic research publications

This class provided a really great opportunity to see how econometrics is used in economics research. I became more comfortable reading and understanding economic papers on a wide variety of topics. The opportunity to present a paper of choice as well as our own senior essay progress was extremely valuable. I really developed my presentation skills.

I got a thorough review and then extension of the topics covered in Intro and Intermediate Econometrics. It was great to apply these skills to understanding economic papers for a more practical understanding and application of the theory.
This class teaches you how to read economics research and papers.
How to build an effective empirical question and model

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: current format is very effective, needs little improvement.

It was tough not being in person, it definitely would have added a lot to the presentations. That said, the course had very great strengths with minimal weaknesses. No busy work (light week to week), but the work that was given was engaging and enlightening. Prof Noguera is really good at engaging with students, providing ample time to receive help, and explaining concepts in pretty easy to reach ways. It does assume a pretty rigorous memory from Metrics, so I would brush up on that material. The student presentations were engaging and a good way to keep the material intersting. FWIW, I think the students should have to sign up for a presentation date earlier in the semester, as its tougher on the people in the beginning.

Strengths: presentations very helpful
Weakness: you have to figure out the psets on your own
Dr Noguera was a great friendly professor. I enjoyed learning about different fields in economics. The assessments were fair.

Strengths: the professor, the interactive presentation format
Weakness: I think the virtual format made it sometimes difficult for everyone to participate effectively.

There's some interesting content in this course, and it's relatively low work load most of the time, but it is sometimes stressful. For example, we had a problem set and midterm within a week of each other, and many students also had presentations in those two weeks, which meant that up to 80% of our grade was dependent on two weeks worth of material -- which can be a challenge around midterms. Professor Noguera is very helpful and available.

The strength of this course was being able to read papers, break them down, and discuss how effective they were.

For improvements, perhaps, having sample presentations could be a resource to some?

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: functioned effectively in virtual setting

Zoom polls in presentations were good, the structure was good, the engagement was as good as could be expected. Frankly, presentations lose a lot from not being in person and this class did as well as could be expected given the circumstances. Maybe incorporate breakout rooms into presentations? Overall, a solid effort and execution for a tough premise
I think the professor was super available for office hours. I went every week and office hours were super helpful in reinforcing course material.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this is a fantastic empirical economics course without a heavy workload

Yes, if you have any interest in econometrics or learning how research works. It doesn't involve you doing any original research, but does give a strong foundation for understanding research that sets you up for the future. Great seminar in that its not too work heavy, but still enough to be engaging, and could be taken as a fifth class. The presentations were also valuable for students going into any field. It wasn't the most riveting course I've ever taken, but it was rewarding and taught me a lot and was more interesting than you would think as generally the students pick interesting topics.
Yes, good for understanding empirical methods in economic research
Yes, absolutely. It's a great survey course on empirical research
Yes. The class can be work at some points if you are not as strong in STATA, but the class is worthwhile.
I would recommend this course to anyone seeking a more practical application of econometrics skills. Professor Noguera is wonderful and the class is very enjoyable.
I would recommend to anyone interested in doing any kind of research at Yale at some point.
